Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: The PictureSTEM Project - Using Picture Books to Transform STEM Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a need for curricula that address STEM standards in an integrated way. The Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSS-M) are research-based academic standards that were created so that U.S. states would have the option to adopt high-quality standards for their students. Each one has concepts and skills that most current curricula do not address. The NGSS include engineering design processes as required concepts and skills for students to learn in conjunction with their science content. The CCSS-M includes process standards such as modeling with mathematics. The Common Core Standards for English Language Arts include standards that ask students to learn technical communication, particularly with a connection to STEM subjects. Each of these separate standards requires realistic contexts for which to situate the learning. Teachers and principals are currently looking for curricula that meet these needs, but integrated curricula are few and far between. The curricula (PictureSTEM) proposed by this I-Corps team integrate all of these ideas into one unit.

The main goal of the PictureSTEM project is to develop an instructional module at each grade level, kindergarten through fifth, which employs engineering and literacy contexts to integrate science, technology, and mathematics content instruction in meaningful and significant ways. These transformative new models for STEM learning use picture books and an engineering design challenge to provide students with authentic, contextual activities that engage learners in specific STEM content as well as integrate concepts across traditional disciplinary boundaries. PictureSTEM units will focus on standards-based engineering, mathematics, and science content, which is different than other curricula currently available. They are research based curricula as described above. These modules have the potential to transform the way literacy and STEM are taught at the elementary level by attending to the learning goals of all areas, therefore, providing a potential framework for the development of an entire elementary curricula in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The PictureSTEM Project includes an instructional unit at each grade level, K-2, which employs engineering and literary contexts to integrate science, technology, mathematics, and computational thinking content instruction in meaningful and significant ways. These transformative new models for STEM+C (science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and computational thinking) learning use picture books and an engineering design challenge to provide students with authentic, contextual activities that engage learners in specific science, mathematics, and computational thinking content while integrating across traditional disciplinary boundaries. Currently, there are limited curricula that address this need for integration. However, one challenge is getting these high-quality, research-based materials into practice in a form that fits with teachers’ current implementation structures. The PictureSTEM units were designed to foster integration, but this goal is only satisfied when teachers are aware of the resources and can put these research-based modules into practice. The results of this I-Corps L project included market research that resulted in: a more explicit translation of the research that addressed the needs of the administrators and teachers interviewed into the curricula; an addition of problem scoping and computational thinking into the PictureSTEM units; a reduction in scope of the PictureSTEM units, reducing from all of K-5 to a focus on K-2 curricula; and an investigation of how to scale up curricula to a wide audience through curriculum publishing outlets while also keeping some versions of the curricula free for electronic download.

Intellectual Merit: This project advances pedagogical understanding about how to teach STEM+C in an interdisciplinary manner and how to translate these evidence-based research findings into broad classroom practice. Additionally, this project extends the knowledge base on how to get products of educational research out into the hands of potential adopters and moving it into a space where these products are available for widespread adoption leading to the possibility for use by teachers and students across the country. The project team includes PI, Dr. Tamara Moore, who has experience in curriculum development and teaching STEM to under-served audiences, as well as implementing state and national standards; the co-PI and primary entrepreneurial lead, Dr. Kristina Tank, who has expertise in literacy and STEM integration, as well as curriculum development experience; and the second entrepreneurial lead, Emilie Siverling, who is experienced in STEM integration, interview methods, and videography.  This project was supported further by the addition of Dr. Christine Cunningham, the founder of the Engineering is Elementary curricula. This team provided a wide-range of elementary STEM education expertise, which helped to further the development of the PictureSTEM curricula units.

Broader Impacts: The current movement to add engineering in elementary classrooms through national and state documents makes STEM+C integration and new models of STEM learning extremely relevant. STEM+C integration has the potential to increase student interest in STEM+C subjects and, therefore, increase the strength and number of students with pathways to enter STEM fields. The inclusion of the literacy component in these STEM integration modules will help to explore other options for new models of STEM learning in elementary classrooms that are tied to literacy outcomes. As more states adopt the Next Generation Science Standards or add engineering into their K-12 academic standards and look at models of STEM learning for their classrooms, there is a clear need for flexible curricula that can act as a model for effective STEM+C teaching and learning. Given the focus on developing literacy skills in the early grades, curriculum with a STEM+C and a literacy focus will not only help to integrate engineering into classroom instruction, but it will also promote meaningful and intentional connections between STEM content fields and an interdisciplinary approach to learning.
